**G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 212, § 4** because this is a civil action for money damages exceeding $50,000 arising in Norfolk County.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 8**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 8** because the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred within Norfolk County, Massachusetts.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Defendant, as an operator of a restaurant open to the public, owed Plaintiff, a business invitee, a **duty of reasonable care** to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition, to inspect for hazards, and to warn invitees of any dangerous conditions of which Defendant knew or should have known.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a concurring opinion focused on critiquing the continued significance of the trespasser category in premises liability. It does not discuss the duty of a restaurant or other business owner to invitees, nor does it describe a duty to inspect or warn. While the full Mounsey majority opinion does broaden occupiers’ duties based on reasonable care, this excerpt alone does not establish or affirm the specific proposition stated about a restaurant’s duty to business invitees.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant, as an operator of a restaurant open to the public, owed Plaintiff, a business invitee, a **duty of reasonable care** to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition, to inspect for hazards, and to warn invitees of any dangerous conditions of which Defendant knew or should have known.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the traditional Massachusetts premises-liability rule for invitees and then reaffirms that same duty of reasonable care as the governing standard for all lawful visitors, including business invitees. It states that owners must use reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe, which includes repairing/removing dangerous conditions or warning of dangers the owner knows or should know of. The case then applies that general reasonable-care standard to snow and ice, abolishing the natural/unnatural distinction, but the underlying invitee-duty formulation matches the proposition.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.” 457 Mass. at 371-372.

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to promptly clean up the liquid and ice on the floor and by failing to warn customers of the dangerous slippery condition.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize that a possessor of business premises has a duty to use due care to keep the premises reasonably safe or to warn of dangers, but the court ultimately holds that the plaintiff failed to prove negligence because there was insufficient evidence that the foreign substance had been on the stairs long enough for the defendant to discover and remove it. Thus, the case does not find that the defendant breached this duty by failing to promptly clean up or warn; instead it concludes the opposite and orders judgment for the defendant. The decision therefore does not support the claimed proposition that the defendant breached its duty in this way.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.”

*Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea.raw_text: *Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.*, 343 Mass. 263 (1961)
*Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to promptly clean up the liquid and ice on the floor and by failing to warn customers of the dangerous slippery condition.
*Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
*Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea.support_reasoning: The case discusses the store’s duty to keep premises reasonably safe, including to discover and remedy or warn of dangerous conditions, but ultimately holds that the plaintiff failed to prove the oil had been on the floor long enough to impose liability. The court reverses a verdict for the plaintiff and orders judgment for the defendant, finding negligence “left to conjecture,” rather than finding that the defendant breached its duty by failing to clean up or warn. Thus, the opinion does not support the proposition that the defendant in this case breached that duty; it supports the opposite outcome on these facts.
*Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use… Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action… On the evidence here we think that the negligence of the defendant is left to conjecture… Judgment for the defendant.”

*Gallant v. Stop & Shop*, 400 Mass. 439.proposition: The dangerous condition was created by Defendant’s own employee, imputing notice to Defendant.
*Gallant v. Stop & Shop*, 400 Mass. 439.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal ineffective-assistance/causation decision and does not involve premises liability, dangerous conditions, or notice in a slip-and-fall or similar context. It nowhere discusses a dangerous condition created by a defendant’s employee or the imputation of notice based on such creation. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition and appears to be a miscitation or wrong case text for the cited caption.
*Gallant v. Stop & Shop*, 400 Mass. 439.relevant_excerpt: “The sole issue on appeal is whether defense counsel’s failure to investigate and pursue the issue of causation of the victim’s death was ineffective assistance of counsel… We therefore reverse the conviction of murder in the first degree and remand that case to the Superior Court for a new trial.”

*Corsetti v. Stone Co.*, 396 Mass. 1 (19.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act with reasonable care constituted negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Corsetti v. Stone Co.*, 396 Mass. 1 (19.support_reasoning: The provided text is a dissent focused entirely on evidentiary issues, specifically the collateral source rule and the trial judge’s discretion in admitting or excluding collateral source evidence. It does not discuss the substantive elements of negligence, reasonable care, or whether the defendant’s conduct constituted negligence under Massachusetts law. Therefore, this excerpt from Corsetti v. Stone Co. does not support the proposition that the defendant’s failure to act with reasonable care constituted negligence under Massachusetts law.
*Corsetti v. Stone Co.*, 396 Mass. 1 (19.relevant_excerpt: "Collateral source evidence has been deemed irrelevant because 'the receipts from the outside source do not go to reduce the defendant's liability; yet jurors might be led by the irrelevancy to consider plaintiffs' claims unimportant or trivial or to refuse plaintiffs' verdicts or reduce them, believing that otherwise there would be unjust double recovery.' Goldstein v. Gontarz, 364 Mass. 800, 809 (1974). Exceptions to any general rule should be cautiously considered, lest the exceptions swallow the rule. That is what the court's opinion today may do with respect to the collateral-source rule."

*Cooper v. Braver*, 401 Mass. 1001 (1988.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act with reasonable care constituted negligence under Massachusetts law.

*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.raw_text: *Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law)
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the **direct and proximate cause** of Plaintiff’s injuries, medical expenses, and lost wages.
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not hold that Massport’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of the specific injuries, medical expenses, and lost wages at issue; it in fact reverses jury awards for the reputation-based components of damages for lack of proximate cause. While the court notes that a prior jury in the liability phase found Massport’s negligence to be a proximate cause of the accident, the decision on appeal turns on the absence of sufficient proof that Massport’s negligence proximately caused the particular claimed losses. Thus, it cannot be cited as authority that defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of those injuries and economic losses.
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “In the liability phase, the jury returned a verdict for the plaintiffs, finding that Massport had been negligent in its maintenance of Logan Airport on January 23, 1982, and that this negligence was a proximate cause of the accident. … The district court overturned the jury's verdict on the ground that the evidence presented in the case ‘was insufficient to support a reasoned finding by the jury that the losses alleged by plaintiffs through harm to reputation were proximately caused by the negligence of Massport.’ … we affirm … due to the plaintiffs' failure to adduce sufficient evidence to support their reputation-damage claims.”

*Bernard v. Gallup*, 352 Mass. 327 (1967.proposition: Plaintiff exercised reasonable care for her own safety at all times and could not have discovered the dangerous condition prior to her fall.
*Bernard v. Gallup*, 352 Mass. 327 (1967.support_reasoning: The opinion is a contract/employment dispute about an agreement to manage pizza shops; it does not involve premises liability, personal injury, or any analysis of a plaintiff’s reasonable care for her own safety or her ability to discover a dangerous condition. Nothing in the holding or reasoning addresses standards of care for an injured plaintiff or discovery of a hazardous condition prior to a fall. Therefore it cannot support the stated proposition.
*Bernard v. Gallup*, 352 Mass. 327 (1967.relevant_excerpt: The case concerns Catania’s performance under an employment contract: “The master concluded that Catania ‘did not use his best efforts as general supervisor and manager’ and ‘in the promotion and management of’ the Dennisport and West Yarmouth businesses. He also concluded, as far ‘as it is a question of fact, that the discharge of . . . [Catania] was warranted.’” This discussion relates to contractual obligations, not personal safety or discovery of dangerous conditions.

*Graci v. Massachusetts Gas Co.*, 7 Mass.raw_text: *Graci v. Massachusetts Gas Co.*, 7 Mass. App. Ct. 221 (1979)
*Graci v. Massachusetts Gas Co.*, 7 Mass.proposition: As a foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligent acts and omissions, Plaintiff sustained injuries and damages.
*Graci v. Massachusetts Gas Co.*, 7 Mass.case_name: Graci v. Massachusetts Gas & Electric Light Supply Co.
*Graci v. Massachusetts Gas Co.*, 7 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that there was sufficient evidence for the jury to infer that the defendant’s negligent failure to maintain its building in a safe condition caused debris to fall and injure the plaintiffs. The court explicitly links the defendant’s negligent acts/omissions (failure to secure defective, boarded-up windows and maintain the building) with the plaintiffs’ injuries, affirming causation and foreseeability as grounds for liability. This directly supports the proposition that, as a foreseeable result of defendant’s negligence, plaintiff sustained injuries and damages.
*Graci v. Massachusetts Gas Co.*, 7 Mass.relevant_excerpt: "In sum, we think that there was sufficient evidence to permit a reasonable inference by the jury, in the absence of any contrary explanation, that the defendant had failed properly to secure defective windows located on the second floor of its building, and that what appeared to have been parts of the boarded-up windows, as well as bricks, glass and masonry sand 'fell in consequence of the failure of the defendant to fasten [them] properly.' … Accordingly, the jury could have found that the plaintiffs’ injuries caused by falling debris were suffered as a result of the defendant’s negligent failure to maintain its building in a proper and safe condition."

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: C. Award statutory interest from the date of commencement of this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
